objectives: Understand the idea of gender for naming words (nouns) in English.
Learn to identify words that have similar meanings (synonyms).
Practice using different words to describe the same thing or idea.

sections.text: The Masculine Gender is used for male persons or male animals. These are words that refer to boys, men, or male animals.

examples.label: Boy
examples.value: A young male person.

examples.label: Man
examples.value: An adult male person.

examples.label: Father
examples.value: Your male parent.

examples.label: King
examples.value: A male ruler of a country.

examples.label: Bull
examples.value: A male cow.

usage_examples: My **father** is a farmer.
The **boy** plays in the field.
The **king** ruled his land well.
We saw a strong **bull** in the village.
My **brother** goes to school.
The **man** is sitting under the tree.

sections.text: The Feminine Gender is used for female persons or female animals. These are words that refer to girls, women, or female animals.

examples.label: Girl
examples.value: A young female person.

examples.label: Woman
examples.value: An adult female person.

examples.label: Mother
examples.value: Your female parent.

examples.label: Queen
examples.value: A female ruler of a country.

examples.label: Cow
examples.value: A female bovine animal that gives milk.

usage_examples: My **mother** cooks delicious food.
The **girl** draws beautiful pictures.
The **queen** wore a beautiful crown.
Our **cow** gives a lot of milk.
My **sister** helps me study.
The **woman** carries water from the well.

subtopics.title: 1.3. Common and Neuter Gender: No Specific Gender

sections.text:
Some nouns do not tell us if they are male or female. These can be: 
1. **Common Gender**: Refers to both male and female. 
2. **Neuter Gender**: Refers to non-living things that have no gender.

examples.label: Common Gender - Student
examples.value: A **student** can be a boy or a girl.

examples.label: Common Gender - Teacher
examples.value: A **teacher** can be a man or a woman.

examples.label: Neuter Gender - Book
examples.value: A **book** has no gender. It's a thing.

examples.label: Neuter Gender - Tree
examples.value: A **tree** has no gender. It's a plant.

examples.label: Neuter Gender - Stone
examples.value: A **stone** has no gender. It's an object.

usage_examples: The **child** is playing. (could be boy or girl)
My **friend** came to visit. (could be male or female)
The **classroom** has many chairs. (chair is neuter)
I bought a new **bicycle**. (bicycle is neuter)
The **bird** is singing. (could be male or female bird)
The **village** has a pond. (village is neuter)

sections.text: Here are some common pairs of masculine and feminine nouns you will often use.

table.title: Masculine and Feminine Nouns
rows: The boy and girl are friends.
A man and a woman stood there.
My father and mother love me.
My brother and sister go to school.
The king and queen are wise.
The prince and princess are happy.
He has a son and a daughter.
My uncle and aunt visited us.
My grandfather and grandmother tell stories.
The cock crows, the hen lays eggs.
The bull and cow are on the farm.
The tiger and tigress live in the jungle.
He is an actor, she is an actress.
The waiter and waitress serve food.

sections.text: Synonyms are words that have the same or very similar meanings. They are like different clothes for the same person. Learning synonyms helps you use different words to say the same thing, making your English richer and more interesting.

examples.label: Big
examples.value: Large (both mean great size)

examples.label: Happy
examples.value: Glad (both mean feeling joy)

examples.label: Fast
examples.value: Quick (both mean moving with speed)

examples.label: Beautiful
examples.value: Pretty (both mean pleasing to the eye)

examples.label: Start
examples.value: Begin (both mean to commence something)

usage_examples: The elephant is a **big** animal. The elephant is a **large** animal.
I am **happy** today. I am **glad** today.
The rabbit runs **fast**. The rabbit runs **quick**.
The flower is **beautiful**. The flower is **pretty**.
Let's **start** the game. Let's **begin** the game.
My bag is **heavy**. My bag is **weighty**.

sections.text: Here are some useful synonyms that you can use in your daily talks and writings. Using different words for the same meaning makes your English better.

table.title: Common Synonyms
rows: We live in a big / large house.
This is a good / fine idea.
That was a bad / poor decision.
We will end / finish the game soon.
I will speak / talk to my friend.
She asked / enquired about the book.
Please answer / reply to the question.
He got a gift / present for his birthday.
He is a rich / wealthy farmer.
She is a smart / clever student.

sections.text:
Learning synonyms is very useful. It helps you:
1. **Avoid repeating words**: You can use different words to keep your sentences interesting.
2. **Understand more**: When you read or listen, you will understand more words and their meanings.
3. **Express yourself better**: You can choose the best word to say exactly what you mean.

examples.label: Better Writing
examples.value: Instead of 'The tree is big. The other tree is also big.', you can say 'The tree is **large**. The other tree is also **huge**.'

examples.label: Clearer Speaking
examples.value: When you are happy, you can say 'I feel **happy**' or 'I feel **joyful**'.

examples.label: Understanding Texts
examples.value: If you read 'The field is **vast**', and you know 'vast' is a synonym for 'big', you understand the field is very big.

usage_examples: Using synonyms makes your writing more beautiful.
My teacher said, 'Try to use different words for 'good'.'
Knowing synonyms helps me understand English stories better.
It's good to have a 'large' vocabulary, meaning a 'big' collection of words.
Can you give me a synonym for 'old'?
This helps me to speak English more clearly and confidently.
